author: Thomas
title: Kay, y'know what?
content: I'm not even going to bother justifying or elaborating upon my 1-star review.  I like to think the reasoning behind it is pretty self-evident.

author: Phoenix Reader
title: I am so disgusted anyone could think this is ok
content: As a parent of a child with Stage IV neuroblastoma, even thinking this title is so wrong. You are not a parent and seriously, you need help. If cancer could be wished on someone, you need to experience it and the devastating loss of a loved child.

author: Audie
title: One Star
content: This is real? hahaha

author: Megan Lee
title: Boycotting Amazon Until This Book Is Removed
content: I am never buying another book from Amazon. Carrying a book with this title has got to be one of the most insensitive, pathetic things I've ever seen. There are many, many things in this life that are worse than Autism. Burying two sons, both babies, for no reason, other than SIDS. Death, is much, much worse than Autism. At least this pathetic author gets to cuddle his children every day. Although, I hope they grow up and realize exactly what he thinks of them. Those poor kids.

author: patricia m wimmer-johnson
title: My son is diagnosed with autism and cancer
content: My son Luke was diagnosed in 2nd grade with ASD, in 8th grade he was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Guess what ASD never threatened my son's life, with ALL he has had a port to pour poison into his body, he has had lumbar punctures to shoot chemo into his spinal fluid, he has to eat chemo pills everyday for for 3 years and 4 months, he has been hospitalized for running a fever, that is not included all the times he was in the hospital for chemo infusions that lasted for hours, lost his hair, his appetite, lost mobility, lost his ability to read for a month because of cranial radiation. At best you are a fool for the title of this book at worst a self absorbed whiny jerk. My son didn't have cancer until he did, I pray you do not get to join the club of parents who have children with cancer

author: Amazon Customer
title: Disgusting!
content: I'm speechless. Are you sure this wasn't written by Donald Trump under a pseudonym? Disgusting!

author: melissa kraft
title: wow really?
content: i hope his kids never find this book. cancer is way worst than autism, would you really want your kids to die? what is wrong with this man?

author: R. Gomez
title: You're dumb!!
content: You're an idiot!! I would have rather of struggled with an autistic child than to watch mine suffer and die from cancer. Amazon, you should seriously consider removing this publication.

author: Lisa
title: Disgusting!
content: You don't deserve to be a parent!

author: Tabatha
title: Pure crap
content: I hated everything about this ableist piece of work.  Vaccines do not cause autism or cancer!!

author: Dani
title: No, just no.
content:
If I could say but two things to Michael Alan, it would be: take some parenting classes, and then take some writing classes. I don't think the order you do those is going to hurt your cause any further than this injurious book has, and that is -- should be -- as sad as it is scary.

As the neurotypical parent to two autistic children, I heard about this book from rightfully outraged members of the autistic community online and then decided to read it on behalf of the ones who had yet to so that they would not have to. Although I share the opinion that the title was in extremely poor taste, having loved ones who have bravely fought against cancer, I wanted to give the book a "fair shot" as it were, reading it in its entirety before I reviewed it here. And what I found was that the contents of the book were actually worse than the title. However, that isn't commendable in its effort.

To address the technical concerns that I have with the book, I found that it jumped tenses a lot. Several chapters were written in the present tense, but some were written in the past tense, and the transition between tenses was not in the most predictable manner. Reading was not smooth for me. The manner of Alan's writing would have better fit a seventh grader.

Although Alan states in the preface of the book that he considers his children to be his greatest gifts and encourages him not to give up, the chapters that follow -- all of them -- indicate that he already has, and that he is fighting a losing battle against his children's differing neurologies. He wants so desperately for his children to be "normal", for the autism to "loosen its grip on his children" that he seems oblivious to the fact that he has two beautiful, worthwhile children right in front of him. They just happen to be autistic. Alan has clearly drunk the Autism Speaks "kool-aid", believing that autism has stolen and locked away these seemingly previously normal children. In doing so, he and his wife employ questionable "treatments": chelation and detoxification supplements used to flush heavy metals out of bodies, erroneously believing that their children's autism was caused by their buildup, special creams and even hyperbaric oxygen treatments. None of these treatments (hence my putting quotations around the word the first time I used it) have ever been proven to help autistic individuals out, but they are the ones that seem to be clung to by those who want to "cure" their child(ren).

Neurological differences, even substantial ones, can not be "cured". They can, however, be aided and assisted with therapy that targets a deficit in an important life skill (such as speaking). They should, and should not, be used to try to make a child that is acting "different" in a harmless manner (flapping, for instance) act less so because they desperately want the child to be "normal". If the child is stimming or moving in a manner that does not hurt them or those around them, why should the neurotypical as a whole be allowed to judge that child's coping mechanisms on the basis that they are "weird"?

My ideology has always been that if you claim to want to help those who are autistic, and you anger or sadden those who are actually autistic in your words and your actions, you are not doing what you claim you want to do. This book just reeks of Alan's desperation to have normal children to the point where he can't be happy with the two children he has right in front of him, and I fear for the day either one of his children might pick up his book themselves and start to read it.

Love your children unconditionally for who they are rather than expecting the impossible of them. Accept their differences.

author: Brich
title: As a parent of a child with cancer I am pretty angry that someone could possibly say that they wish ...
content: Offensive, inappropriate title and book. As a parent of a child with cancer I am pretty angry that someone could possibly say that they wish their child had cancer. Cancer is hard on the child, parents, and the rest of the family. I don't care what he was trying to say, having a child with cancer and a child with autism shouldnt be compared against each other. They both are extremely hard. And FYI, most parents of children with cancer would much rather prefer they were autistic, especially the ones who have lost their children.

author: Tiffany
title: Disgusting
content: How did this get published? If I could give less than one star, I would. Clearly Mr. Alan is crying for attention.

author: Jenna Rose Marder
title: You're A Cancer
content:
Wow, really? Maybe you should have cancer and then your autistic kid(s) can have a normal, decent parent. You should never have had kids to begin with. I'm
autistic and I find it disgusting you hate your children. Yes. Hate.

author: Allymae
title: Horrid and Ableist
content: Anyone who agrees with this book should not be a parent. I feel so bad for your children. I am VERY glad my autistic fiancé and best friend don't have cancer. They're great just the way they are.

author: Laura Witt
title: WTF
content: This book promotes hatred and genocide of those with disabilities.

author: Sherry
title: OMG!
content: I was walking through the education section at Barnes and Noble today and did a double take when I saw the title of this book.  Being the parent of a child with cancer, I have to ask how many times he had to watch his child have bone marrow aspirations?  spinal taps?  blood transfusions?  chemo drips?  How many parties, school events, family gatherings, or play dates did his kids have to miss because they were too sick or their immune systems were too fragile to be exposed to germs??  Did he ever have to worry that the common cold could KILL his children?? How many times did he lay in bed at night wondering if the treatment would work just so his child could live?  Mr. Alan, be careful what you wish for.

author: Jodie R.
title: Absolutely No
content: Absolutely No. This thought is horrific and disgusting. To wish cancer upon any family member is malicious. Children do not die or suffer painfully from Autism, they do sometimes from cancer.

author: Leo d'Entremont
title: Right. Uh-huh.
content:
I'm autistic. I was only diagnosed as an adult because despite my severe social struggles, I was fully verbal and very academically gifted. Sure, life was more difficult sometimes, but I like who I am now. Being autistic isn't the end of the world. We're each fully unique individuals with talents and emotions and the ability to enjoy life as much as anybody else.

I'm a published author, an Army veteran, and a happily married man with an amazing wife. I have friends, a job, and multiple college degrees. I have hobbies and a social life that is perfectly suited to me. I attend conventions, speak in front of huge crowds, and enjoy costume competitions. I've performed in musicals, sung barbershop, and love karaoke. Sure, I still get overstimulated sometimes. When I was younger, I had no clue how to socialize (even though I desperately wanted to, and longed to be accepted) and had severe anxiety and depression because I felt so alone. I used to have outbursts. However, I don't anymore. I got the help I needed. I found the most amazing woman in the world who has been with me for almost nine years, and has helped me to become the man I am today. I have friends who understand me. I'm happy and functional with a full, rich life.

Or maybe I should have died of cancer as a child. It would have been better, right? That's what this author seems to think.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Hate speech
content: This is yet another instance of parents demonizing autism and being rewarded for it. Horrible, abusive, hate speech.

author: Bloo
title: Absolutely awful.
content:
This is offensive to autistic people and to people who have dealt with cancer. It’s ableist tripe. This person deserves to lose custody of their children forever. If you think that autism is just so horrid that you wish your children were dead, you are an awful parent and person.

To the kids in this book and anyone else who’s autistic: you have amazing worth and value.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Absolutely Disgusting
content: If I could give this negative stars I would. Who wishes a potentially deadly illness on their children? So your children are Autistic, they were born that way and you should love them. You might as well have written a book saying you wished your children were dead because cancer does kill children...Autism doesn't. You have no business having children and hopefully they will be removed from your custody.

author: mujababy
title: Amazon allows hate mongering against Autistics.
content: Are you kidding me! I have 2 AUTISTIC children but unlike the author of this book I know autism is not a disease and I also know their neurology is *not* about me. What a disgusting piece of tripe you're allowing to be peddled here Amazon.

author: OldandTired
title: My child has cancer and it left him with PDD NOS
content:
I didnt rate this book (so the monitor lady wouldnt be upset)but Amazon insisted so I gave it a five star rating to undo all of the one marks by the other parents. Do you think that is fair now? I hope so because I am so THANKFUL that you thought of it and insisted on letting the rest of us know how "UNFAIR" it is to rate a book....and the "DONT YOU DARE" ALMOST (but didnt) stop me in my tracks. We all know how it feels when someone scolds us.  I did have to pipe in on this.
Everyone has their cross to bare in life.  Luckily for most, cancer is not one of them.  For the unlucky few it is and because of "WHEN" our child developed Leukemia/started treatment (age 23 months) he has now been diagnosed with autism.  He also was treated for PTSD.
All I want you to know is dealing with the Autism is nothing compared to dealing with the cancer.  To watch your child being given chemicals that might kill them and makes them very ill and causes incredible pain is not fun, enjoyable etc. For almost four years our child endured chemo not to mention all of the deadly infections that we did not know if he would live through. Secondary cancers are probable, as well as recurrence of the original cancer.  We as parents of REAL CHILDREN with cancer have to deal with all of not so important things such as loss limbs, eyes, ability to walk, brain damage, autism and the psychological damage etc that the cancer treatment has done to our children. You are given the perception that 80% of children are cured. When I asked if our child was cured our doctor said "When he is married with children and in his thirties I will consider your child cured".  Everyday we wait for the beast to return and ravage our child. With Autism life goes on.....
As my husband has said with all of his military honors/medals. "Cancer has brought me to my knees".  Autism has not. EVERYDAY we give thanks that our little one is with us and he gives us so much joy. Autism and all~

author: Mr. J. Drummond
title: I'm perplexed that you would even consider wanting to watch your child suffer and possibly die from cancer.
content:
Having watch my son from the tender age of 6 months be treat for cancer, then whilst 18 months old be told by the doctors there is nothing else they can do, so kiss him on the forehead.  I'm a little concerned you would wish that upon your own children.  I consider myself very blessed my son has survived 4 years post end of treatment, and even though he has lifelong disabilities. Which will most certainly mean he will struggle with certain tasks in life, he is here and growing up amongst his siblings and parents.  The same can't be said for thousands of other children diagnosed with cancer.
I have met and know so many families who have lost a beautiful soul to the ravages of cancer, so many wonderful families shattered by the diagnosis.  I also know lots of families with beautiful children with autism who adapt and cope with the many challenges that diagnosis brings them.
Those families can hold and kiss their child goodnight and be thankful for the blessing of parenthood.  To wish you went from that paradigm into the one where if you are lucky your child survives treatment and doesn't die,  is perplexing if not rather worrying.

author: Jennifer Burke
title: My child has both.. autism and cancer. ...
content: My child has both..autism and cancer.  This author should be careful what he wishes for!  I have not read the book but came across it on Amazon and can not help but be disturbed by the title.  Shame!

author: Audrey Schmitt
title: One Star
content: I wish your kids had a loving father who accepted them as they are. This is disturbing.

author: Nahomi Dolieta
title: A title disturbing to those with both autism and cancer
content: My daughter, my only child, was a special education teacher. Her classrooms always had several young students with autism. She not only taught those children, but worked with their parents. I watched her suffer the ravages of cancer and its treatments for several years. Then, she died, leaving two babies. I run the Family Resource Center at a university, and can not recommend this book - the title is just too shocking and demeaning. While the title may serve its purpose by drawing people to read the contents of the book, it is still heartless in my eyes. My daughter so wanted to live. I wish my child didn't have cancer. I wish no one's child got cancer or had to live with autism. But, it HAPPENS, and we do the best we can with family, friends, and community support. My best healing wishes to the author and his children.

author: RoseP728
title: Horrible
content: I don't care about his reasoning for that horrific title, but it is insensitive idiotic at best. I bet his kids will feel great knowing this is how their father feels about them. My daughter suffered from a stroke at birth. She has learning disabilities, left side hemeparesis and faces challenges every day. As hard as some days are, I am grateful she is alive and would never wish cancer on her or anyone for that matter.

author: K. Douglas
title: Discriminatory and disturbing
content: I Wish This Book Had Cancer. What is wrong with you? You would literally rather your child suffer and perhaps die than for you to have to face the challenges associated with autism? Parenting fail and human being fail.

author: Realbinky
title: Autism is not an epidemic, this author is a POS
content: Autism is not an epidemic, it just is.  The kids are not sick, or injured or damaged.  Just different.  Wishing cancer and death on kids, saying it would be better than autistic is disgusting.  I can't swear here, or Amazon would not post it, but I have some choice words in my head for the author and to describe what a horrible piece of human garbage he is.

author: Terry W.
title: Evil peathitc pesent
content: The fact Amazon is letting this be sold is disheartening. This shows a lack of compassion and empathy for any child. This is the type of person who should be sterilized and not have children.

author: Angela D. Fox
title: Offensive, at best.
content:
I have three children. One is neuro typical and at a high genetic risk for cancer. One had cancer AND autism. One has autism and is healthy.

Cancer killed my 8 year old daughter. I did all I could to save her, and she's gone.
Not once has it even crossed my mind that perhaps if my surving child with autism had cancer his issues would be more socially acceptable , or perhaps we'd get more community support. I look at him and feel grateful that he's alive and healthy and I have the OPPORTUNITY to help him navigate this world. Is it frustrating and heartbreaking at times?  Of course!  But it's nothing compared to the grief I walk through every single day since 12/12/08, and the helplessness I felt watching my child's body fail her and cause pain and suffering for nearly 5 years.

This title is offensive, at best. Good luck with sales...and explaining to your adult children why you wished their lives were in danger instead of facing neurological differences.

author: maxtastic mama
title: revolting
content: what the hell is wrong with this guy? a prime example of someone who oughtn't have been permitted to breed... well, here's what i wish, pal - i wish my autistic child would give you a swift kick in the pants...

author: Miss R Lewis
title: insulting book that deserves no stars for being so appalling
content: I find this book deeply insulting. My 7 year old son was diagnosed with Leukaemia when he was 5 and ASD when he was 6, I can hand on heart say that the cancer is far worse. I have had to watch my child fight and suffer daily for 3 years, we wont know if he's beaten this for the next 10 years and there's still all the dreadful side effects that he will have for life.The ASD is hard work, but won't kill him! What parent would ever wish cancer upon their child?

author: Duane K.
title: ... given this book as a gag gift and its horribly written, racially intolerant of people with aspergers as ...
content:
I was given this book as a gag gift and its horribly written, racially intolerant of people with aspergers as a race, and one of the most offensive books i have ever read.  I'm honestly sure that the author is either insane or a massive troll because nobody who is sane could be this offensive.

The book publishing company should be ashamed, the author should be ashamed, and people who buy the book should be ashamed, and all die because lets face it the world is better without this book.

author: Morgan Strange
title: Kids with autism become adults
content: As an autistic i get so sick ad tired of this crap, your children will grow up, they will read this book, and it will hurt them, autism isn't a death sentence, cancer so often is, how the hell can you even compare the two? Do you know how much it hurts when your own parents think you are a burden? when your own parents would rather you had a fatal disease than be who you are? your children are people, and they understand way more than you think they do, just because they have trouble putting their feelings into words doesn't mean that they don't take in everything you say. Shame on you!

author: stringmaster28
title: a masterpiece of sarcastic literature
content: a masterpiece of sarcastic literature. my children have no diseases, but after reading this book, I sorta wish they all had cancer. how much easier it would be!  (this book is sarcasm, right?  right?!)

author: A. Hopper
title: Sociopathy
content: My child has a "good cancer" with an 85% 5 year survival rate.  He also has about a 5% chance of having a normal lifespan.  It take a a special kind of sociopath to belittle our suffering.

author: FriedaW
title: horrible
content:
I have an adult son with autism, and I lost my oldest daughter to cancer at age 24.  This book horrifies me.  What kind of people are they?

I hope to God above that they never know what losing a child to cancer is like.

author: Awieck
title: Icky, awful!
content: Terrible, awful book! Don't buy, don't read!!!! Zero Stats......

author: Lisa B. Molina
title: Very Offensive Title from a Cancer Mom.
content:
As the mother of a child who has fought leukemia 3 times (ages 3,11,13), enduring 8
years of chemotherapy, and now lifeling health issues, -not to mention a friend of too many parents of children who have died (5 children's funerals in my town alone of children I knew personally) I am quite offended by the title of this book.  I am also a teacher of children ages 3-5 with special needs,  which sometimes can include children with autism. As someone who has only a small understanding of living and parenting a child, or children in this case, with autism, I still cannot believe the callous insensitivity of the title. I'm wondering how the parents of children with autism would repond to a book by a parent who lost their child to cancer, "I Wish My Child Had Had Autism."  Does this author realize that some children with brain tumors or those who receive cranial radiation for leukemia sometimes have severe neurological life long effects, even traumatic brain injury?  I hope the best for him and his family and do not doubt the daily pain  and challenges they face,  but as families who are struggling, we need  to be supporting each other, not comparing who has the worst deal in life.

author: Michelle Donovan
title: Some people should never be parents.  This "man" is one of them.
content:
I haven't read this book, and never will.  Not only will I never read this garbage, but I will never again buy anything from Amazon.  Any company that sees fit to sell this kind of offensive, ableist material isn't a company I will ever support.

I sincerely hope that the so-called "father" who wrote this trash never gets his wish.  And I hope that his children (who deserve so much better than to have a "parent" like him) don't ever read what he wished upon them.

author: Gaawa
title: You know what I wish?
content: I wish this "parent" didn't have custody of his children.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Shocked and appalled!
content: I am appalled! How dare you! My daughter was born with cancer and died in my arms. My other daughter survived but we spent months in patient in the hospital with her near death. You wish your child had cancer? I challenge you to go spend a month in a children's cancer ward. Go unprepared like all of us had to. Take only what you are wearing. Leave all your medications at home because you think you'll be back home soon. Forget taking extra clothes, you don't have time and you won't have time to shower and put them on anyway. Your child is ill and needs you now. don't worry about your job. You can take unpaid leave and in time lose it. Don't worry about the bills, they will add up and you'll be living in poverty. My child didn't deserve to die and neither do any of the other children in the cancer ward. How dare you insinuate that a child with cancer has a better chance and opportunity than your child with autism. How could you demean a disease so much? I cannot even begin to express my anger over your book title. I read a few pages and that was enough. You have no idea what a parent of a child with cancer goes through. You are insulting all of these children. I beg you to rename your book and spend some time getting to know a few children with cancer. I challenge you to spend an unexpected month in a cancer ward as described above.

author: SIDZDABOY
title: Sobering insight into challenges of raising special needs children.
content: "I Wish My Kids Had Cancer" will give you a clear insight into the challenges faced by the parents of an autistic child. In this case, two children. It chronicles the ups and downs, sleepless nights, financial difficulties, etc., but more so, it really clearly shows societies misunderstandings about Autism.  You'll be amazed, and angered, at the difficulties faced by the author and his wife as they try to accomplish seemingly simple tasks, like getting straight answers from doctors and educators who claim to have his families best interest in mind, but are numb, or indifferent to their plight.  Interactions with other parents who seem to believe that their children might become infected with autism are especially frustrating, and clearly re-enforce the fact that many people have no idea what Autism is, or how devestating it can be.

author: Christopher L. Sommers
title: Wow. Just wow.
content: This has got to be a joke right? Is this an Andrew Wakefield / Jenny McCarthy joint feature? This is disgusting.

author: Milkman
title: Three Stars
content: Innovative story telling.

author: AspieMom
title: It's the truth.
content: At least there's a little hope with cancer. There's no hope for children with autism. My daughter has Asperger's and she's constantly embarrassing everybody with her lack of social graces. She refuses to participate in any sort of therapy. Medications don't quiet or calm the symptoms. There's no palliative for it. She's always going to be autistic and she's never going to fit in anywhere, I don't care how smart she is. At least with cancer there's a cure or there's death. Autism isn't that easy.

author: Krissy Cano
title: This is offensive
content: I don't have words for how disgusting this is. This man should never be allowed near children, autistic or otherwise.

author: Miriael Mim
title: Cancer?
content:
Discriminatory language as based on a disability. If this book were about children with Downs Syndrome would it have even made it past a reviewer?

I find it ironic that this kind of bigotry and hypocrisy exists in modern times.

author: Hillary Dina
title: What's the deal with cancer?
content:
Remember that episode of Seinfeld where Jerry was purposely trying to throw his act so the comedian following him would suffer having to perform to an angry audience and right before the scene cut Jerry said "and what's the deal with cancer?"

Apparently the "author" of this book never saw that episode.

Ogh, and on another note I can't wait until he publishes the sequel I Wish My Wife Had Aids.

author: Amazon Customer
title: horrified
content: I wonder if the author's kids share his wish. I wonder if they would appreciate being portrayed as such living disasters, such walking hardships to their martyred parents.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The most disgusting thing I have ever had the misfortune to read
content: If I could give this book zero stars, I would do it. What kind of disgusting human being says they wish their child had cancer instead of autism. I can't even put into words how abhorrent a statement that is. It is insulting to the actual victims of childhood cancer, who face death every single day. It is also a slap in the face to every child with autism, and their parents. How dare you even begin to compare your journey with autism (which is NOT GOING TO KILL YOUR CHILD) to the journey cancer patients endure. How dare you?! You don't deserve to have a child with autism. They are too good for you. I pray that your child never learns how you feel about them.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Wow.
content: I have to admit I've never read this book but I am appalled.  I have autism and also live in severe, crushing levels of pain due to a genetic condition.  My autism can cause me a lot of trouble because I am gullible, very sensitive, and become easily overwhelmed and overstimulated.  I have been manipulated by people who take advantage of my inability to detect deception because of my problem with theory of mind.  However, in comparison to the pain I experience on a daily basis, it's NOTHING.  NOTHING.  I've never had cancer, but my friend is currently dying of cancer and she is still in pain while on massive amount of opiates.  I live in pain that is so bad that has caused me to contemplate suicide, and it is not as bad as what she is experiencing.  Endless pain you cannot imagine.  Basically you're saying you'd rather your children live in horrific pain and possibly die rather than accept your children as individual human beings who one day may see this book and know how their father felt about them.

author: Jade Walker
title: I am a cancer?
content: I have autism. Is this saying that I am worse than cancer? Saying things like that about us really hurts. Why do people do it?

author: Louise Parker
title: Did you consider your children at all?
content:
In the Title and blurb alone, the Author has not only wished cancer on his children, but implied that they are 'bad' aspects of his family. I feel sorry for his children should they ever learn about this book. Did the Author not consider their feelings at all? Did he not stop to think how he'd react if he discovered that his Father had wished a potentially fatal illness on him? Or has he come to class people on the autistic spectrum as so strongly 'other' that he failed to even realise they could be affected by this? And then there's people who've dealt with cancer! Surely he sees how horrific this title could seem to them? How it could trivialise something they know to be serious? In fact, did he consider anyone at all when writing his sensationlist headline, or was he only concerned about provoking as much sympathy as possible?

And the sad thing is, I reckon he'd still insist that it's autistic people who lack empathy...

author: Tammy L. Cook
title: the title alone is disgusting! A Must-Not-Read IN MY OPINION.
content: I say burn this book! I know freedom of speech prevents that tho but I have Asperger's Synndrome & my family DID & DOES think I'm a living disaster! They never accepted me & I was institutionalize! Thanks a lot for reinforcing the already low self-esteem that some of us have thanks to years of being made to feel like we're better off dead.

author: Sarah
title: Disgusting excuse of a parent
content: Sickening. Anyone giving this book a 5 star rating and praising this book is straight trash. I don’t care how much of a struggle having kids on the spectrum is. Everyone has it rough for so many different reasons. Cancer is a terrible disease that tears apart families and forces you to watch your loved ones die slowly. How dare you say you wish your children have cancer because they’re difficult for you to handle. Go to parenting classes or put your kids with people who will actually try to take care of them and love them. I hope your kids aren’t functional enough to know you published a book saying you wish they have cancer. I can’t even imagine knowing my parent did that. You’re disgusting.

author: S. Evans
title: Really?
content: The horrifying title made me feel ill- you wish cancer on your kids? You consider them part of an epidemic? Seriously?- and the description bears all the warning signs that this is just more of the same about how much of a "burden" autistic people are and how "brave" this allistic dude is for putting up with his kids. Skip this garbage and find something written by an actual autistic person instead.

author: D, C, Bonyak
title: What a horrible read!
content: What a horrible thing to wish on a child!  Cancer kills!  Autism is may be tough on a child and a parent but it isn't deadly...what a nasty book!

author: Cecilia
title: Appalling
content:
This is heartrending. When I saw this title I thought it was a sarcastic Facebook meme poking fun at parents who catastrophise.

To find its real is just too much. Reading some of the reviews here I can see I am not the only one.

I work with people who have cancer. To wish that on your own child says do much about who you are and how much you understand about the world. None of it good!

I also have autism. Believe me autism is NOT worse than cancer.

The title of this book is inflammatory, offensive, ablist, outrageous and heartbreaking.

It doesn't matter what's in it (though there is no 'look inside' to give us a clue)

I'm all for freedom of speech and publishing rights and all but this is a book I would gladly see pulled from the public eye. It ought to be a crime to portray a human condition so many live with as worse than cancer.

I have to stop because I am just going to keep repeating myself. This book is wrong wrong wrong.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Why would you say this??
content: How could a father ever say that they wish their child had cancer instead of autism. I have an autistic friend and I love him just the way he is, why can't you love your child just the way they are?

author: Kiana
title: Written by literally the most horrible person alive
content:
This is absolutely repulsive. This person who wrote this book is a horrid individual. He does NOT deserve the children he has.
I cannot even believe what I just read.
Jesus, get help!

author: hometree
title: My daughter has autism and cancer
content: I was hoping there would be some help for me dealing with a child with autism and cancer, but instead this title pops up.  Out of fairness, I will not give this book one star because I haven't read it yet.  Although I doubt I have the time to read it.  But, I will just say that I understand how devastating it is to feel that you are losing your sweet three year old to autism.  But it really angers me to read this title, because you do not wish your child had cancer.  You wish you would get the sympathy that parents of children with cancer get.  It is little consolation and doesn't last very long.  Even though there has been significant advancements in cures for various childhood cancers, the treatment for cancer is torturous and almost as harmful as cancer itself. Even if my daughter survives into adulthood, she has a great chance of developing other cancers or diseases during her life.  You can't imagine how cancer treatment affects a young child with autism.  She has lost so much developmental ground since getting sick.  You really can't compare the two issues.  One is a neurological disorder and one might not kill your child if all goes well.  There are so many good interventions and therapies now for our children with autism, there is hope now.  I understand your feelings, but using this title just makes you sound selfish.  I hope with all my heart that your children don't get cancer, but I do wish you would change this title.

author: KatieMo
title: Disgusting book!
content: This book is garbage and the author is a terrible person for writing it. I hope no one supports this author or buys this book.

author: Audrey Sterling
title: One Star
content: I wish Michael Alan had cancer.

author: Michelle Tait
title: Utter disgust. Wish I could give it less than zero stars.
content: This is utter trash. This man would rather his children suffer horrifying and drawn out battles from a mostly terminal illness than be neurodivergent. What a hellish slap in the face to every autist out there and an extra one for everyone battling cancer. This book should be burned.

author: Sharon F
title: Disgusting way to market a book
content:
I have an autistic son, and lost my mother to cancer when she was in her forties. I would not ever for even a second wish that my delightful, sometimes difficult, always loved child has to deal with the agony she suffered. I do not understand anyone attempting to sell a book with such a contentious, damaging title. It is revolting. Shame on you and shame on Amazon and any other company for selling this.

Nothing contained in this book will make it worth reading after this deliberately provocative title. Instead of wishing your children had a horrible and mostly fatal disease, grow up, deal with it and learn how to be a father.

author: Erin
title: Offensive and Triggering
content: I don't understand how you can wish this upon someone, nevertheless your own child. Cancer isn't a joke and I'm sure many families would give anything to have their kids cured. People pay a lot of money for treatment and it's emotionally harmful. I do understand how autism can be hard to deal with but it is never ok to be this immature about it. What a great role model for  his children.

author: goingcoastal
title: Disgusting
content: I feel sorry for this pathetic excuse of a parent's children. Walk in the shoes of someone whose child DOES have cancer and then complain. Jerk.

author: Rachel
title: Just Plain Sick
content: Okay, so what the hell? I don't even want to know what this book's deal is. The title is disgusting, and offensive.

author: Jia-Li
title: Alexa, play "Why is this even a thing?"
content: Parents like the author are exactly why I am pro abortion.  People like this simply should not have children.  The author should give his children up to someone who actually has compassion, surely they cannot be appropriately caring for their children while writing books like this.

author: Kathleen
title: If I could give this zero stars I would
content: This is disgusting. I can't believe somebody actually thinks this is acceptable. Autism is hard to deal with but it's insulting to both the autism and cancer communities to wish your children had cancer instead. Both are financially and emotionally difficult to deal with and it's despicable to assume you have it worse than somebody else because your children are autistic. Yes, it's hard, but it's your job as a parent to love them anyway.

author: Gracie V
title: Pretty glad I only have autism.
content: Typical neurotypical crap. I came here just to give a bad review.

author: C. Tyjewski
title: How to tell you're being played (as a writer or a buyer) of a book.... Or, why one should never self-publish
content:
Why one should never self-publish.... Now, for the average published writer (i.e. those of us who have gotten paid to publish), this seems like an obvious statement. I mean, if you are the means for the pleasure, why are you paying to be pleasured?  But, perhaps, that is too coarse a question. Or, perhaps, this linguistic endeavor is above Alan's course level.... Since he has such a problem with tense, I would suggest relieving some tension but that prescription is well above my paid grade and, clearly, well above his diction and his fiction.  Ah, but this is a review of his...writing.  Yes, what can I say? It was a trite little piece of misinformation written by a man with little thought, no imagination, education and lacking in English vocabulary skills. If one wishes to know anything about the Autistic community, one might contact the various activist groups run by people who are on the autism spectrum and/or look up information regarding cancer or various other disabilities themselves. Clearly, Mr. Alan did not.

If one wishes to throw one's money away, I have two beautiful pieces of waterfront property for sale: one is in between Brooklyn and Manhattan; and, the other, is a lovely piece in the middle of the Everglades......  [This is in no way an advertisement or a sales pitch. For anyone who doesn't realize it, the aforementioned "properties" are commonly "sold" scams: the infamous Brooklyn Bridge and swampland in Florida. I have no intention or desire to sell either one.]

author: Katja
title: You can't please everyone...
content:
Funny story. My friend's kid DID have cancer; it killed him. He didn't make his third birthday.

She wishes he'd had autism. Because then he'd still be alive for her to love and care for. This book is an outrage.

author: brh
title: Eye catching title is no excuse
content:
I understand that a book needs a eye catching title to sell.  but this one is beyond excusable.
I lost my husband to cancer.  AND I am autistic and raised and autistic son. So I think i can say that from the title alone, I understand how hard it is to have a child with an invisible handicap.  schools, strangers, family all condemn you for not drugging or spanking the autism out of them.
But to say that you would rather your child have cancer?  Let the author sit with hospice or chemo patients fighting cancer.  They will thank God that their child has a life and a chance to live.

This may possibly be a well written book, but with the horrid title and premise, it will never be read by many except those who believe that people with autism should be aborted or institutionalized to allow "normal" lives for the rest of the family.  yes, I heard that from a family member.
Just another program the Nazis used to purify the race, get rid of the imperfects.  forget what we can learn from them.

author: tumblr
title: Um...
content: I am honestly disappointed, thats all i can say really, disappointed that this is an actual book. also a bit disgusted.

author: Richard Padilla
title: Don't get this book.
content: I'm not even going to read this book. After I wrote this, this book, to me, will cease to exist. My son is autistic. And I would never wish him to have cancer. My son is amazing. Even this he isn't fully verbal he still gets his point across. I honestly wish that Misery was true and that you played James Caans part.

author: Carlos Spicyweiner
title: One Star
content: This is disgusting.

author: Amber Baumbach
title: Disgusting
content: My six-year-old just passed away from cancer.  She fought nearly her whole life and endured unimaginable pain and suffering.  Obviously the author knows nothing about childhood cancer, or he would not wish this on anyone, let alone his own children.  I'm appalled at the ignorance of the title of this book.  I wish my daughter had autism because that means she would still be here.  Shame on you, Michael Alan.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Eugenics is still alive and well!
content: Should have called it: "I Wish I Lived in 1937 Germany So I Could Have a Better Excuse to Actually Kill My Kids and Not Simply Wish It So."

author: Danielle Rudolph
title: What in the holy hell is wrong with you?
content: I WISH.....I was able to have this booked banned. How absolutely disgusting. Are you kidding? What in the actual hell is wrong with you?

author: ilamonihowie
title: To say you wish your children had cancer is like saying you wish they were dead
content: My daughter is dead. She lived 7 years, 6 of them fighting cancer. To say you wish your children had cancer is like saying you wish they were dead. Is autism really that bad? Give them up for adoption. I'm sure there are plenty of people out there that would love your children and embrace their autism.

author: Kimberly Agostino
title: Wow - this book blew me away....
content: Being a mother of a 3 year old on the Autism Spectrum, I could relate to everything this gifted author wrote.  It felt like having a comrade in this crazy journey through the spectrum.  His story is compelling and shows the courage and strength of he and his wife dealing with two children on the spectrum.  It shows you that "you are not alone" and also challenges parents to stand up and fight for their children's rights in the school system, in regards to care, insurance companies and overall just advocating for your children's rights.  The "cancer" reference may offend some but if you read this book, you understand where the author is coming from and as a mother of a child on the spectrum, I understand.  I truly believe that insurance companies and government entities are covering up a lot in regards to the causes of autism for fear of a mass lawsuit - this pertains to vaccinations as well as other potential causes (amalgam fillings, rhoGam shots, environmental items such as household cleaners, pesticides,etc.) We may never know the cause and correct treatments but we'll die trying to find out - thank you Michael for your book - you are a true hero to your children - keep up the good work with your lovely wife!

author: Jess K
title: You're horrible for writing this about your child
content: What trash. You're horrible for writing this about your child. You're everything that's wrong with neurotypical/allistic "autism parents." I hope your children survive your disdain for their brains.

author: AmyS
title: Sick and offensive ableist trash.
content: Only a truly disgusting human being could say such things about children. It’s offensive to children with autism AND cancer. Wow.

author: abbymeg
title: Awful, sensationalist title that is offensive to many
content: My daughter has Autism. She has also had cancer. Autism can be tough, but cancer is heartbreaking. It the most horrendous, painful thing for a parent to see their child go through. The title of this book is both irresponsible and offensive. Children with autism also have feelings and I hope they never see the title of the book.

author: Rebecca Rettig
title: Disgusting
content: Absolutely disgusting title for a book. I have friends and family that have battled cancer. I wouldn't wish that on anyone.  I also have absolutely wonderful friends with autism. Saying they would be better off with cancer is despicable. Anyone that buys this book is part of the problem. So sad parents think this way about their children

author: Amanda
title: I am EXTREMELY disappointed in Amazon for even allowing this to be on ...
content: I don't care what a single word inside this book has to say. This is appalling. I am EXTREMELY disappointed in Amazon for even allowing this to be on their website. Shame on you and shame on amazon. Disgusting. You should be grateful for your amazing children. There are thousands of parents out here who lost their children to cancer.

author: charlotte
title: Crappy Pity Party Memoir
content:
My sister has autism and i would never want her to ever hear of this book. She is the most wonderful and interesting person. Her differences have already lowered her self esteem...I couldn't even imagine what this disgusting book would do.
In no way did I feel my family was ever "surviving" anything. All I new was i had a fun sister, and my parents had a sweet daughter. Sure, they had to take her to a few more dr. appointments, deal with some horrible medication side effects, tutor and teach more, and stick their necks out for proper accommodations in schooling. But, they never complained about it. Because that is what a parent does they take care of their child; they don't write crappy pity party memoirs.

author: emily
title: awful
content: this is one of the most appalling things i have ever seen. how could a father write something like this about his own children?

author: Amanda
title: Awful
content:
Wishing cancer on your two child, on your own flesh and blood says a lot about you, considering most would not wish such a horrific thing on their worst enemy.

I hope to see this book off the shelf for the Autism community. By leaving this out there we are promoting the idea that having CANCER is better than being AUTISTIC. At the same time we are demeaning those who have cancer by making it "no big deal." Autistic children who struggle enough to fit in on a daily basis definitely do not need to add this to their list of insecurities.

author: Jared's Mom
title: My kid had cancer and I just wish he had been HEALTHY
content: I don't care what's inside the book the title is totally insulting. My kid had cancer and it was the WORST THING EVER. Don't compare your troubles to mine and as a parent feel that your struggles are somehow worse. We all have difficulties as parents and we deal with them. There is no need to compare miseries and insist you somehow ended up more miserable. Please.

author: vikki purcell
title: My child who has Autism and Cancer...I choose my Son..cancer free
content: As a parent of a child with both autism and terminal cancer..I think I can make a educated informed response. This title disgusts me and I do not understand how it could be published. Shame on you author and publishing company. I know which I would choose. ..my loving son with behavioural problems..with autism. ..Over his horrid suffering from cancer. You should all be very ashamed...I hope NO ONE buys this piece of utter miss information trash.

author: Kelly K
title: Appaling!!
content: I have autism, and this disgusts me! Autism is a BLESSING for me, not a curse! This book is extremely abusive and ignorant!

author: Liz
title: What Publisher Greenlit This Title??????
content:
I am beyond aghast that anyone would think that this is an acceptable title for a book, regardless of what it contains. Although I find it extremely difficult to imagine that this author has anything to say that doesn't frame all neuroatypical people as a burden, a waste and a disappointment in a neurotypical world.

Please don't give this person money. He published a book wishing death over autism for his own children as the title. I mean, that alone should be enough.

author: Ami Fox
title: Horrible!
content:
I cannot believe this man would prefer his children to have something that could KILL them, over being autistic! Absolutely disgusting. I have not, and will not, read this book.

My best friend's son is severely autistic. MY son has had 11 years of in and out of the hospital with innumerable procedures, surgeries, labs, infections, 2 organ transplants, and chemo TWICE, all caused by the same rare cancer.

My friend has many times she's glad her son has autism and not Histiocytosis, because she doesn't think she could deal with all this. I always tell her I'd rather keep what I've got and admire her ability to take care of her son. We each have a different type of "patience".

Don't ever wish your loved one has this or that instead.

Before Histiocytosis was finally labeled a cancer, people would say "at least it's not cancer" when hearing of someone's diagnosis with this disease. Makes my blood boil. Here's what cancer (that's not cancer) has done to my son:

https://m.facebook.com/afox73/albums/10151035401846137/?ref=bookmarks

author: xander
title: Garbage
content: You are a joke. Just like this ignorant book. I would love to smack you in the mouth. Garbage

author: E James
title: to the author of this book: You don't deserve ...
content: to the author of this book: You don't deserve those kids. You have failed them in the most public way possible. You have failed as a parent and as a human being. This book is trash from cover to rotten cover. Amazon please, remove this horrific book from your site.

author: G D
title: One Star
content: Wow. This is awful. As a purpose living with incurable cancer, I wish I had autism.

author: Evie
title: I actually have autism you jerk!
content:
I have Autism and I am a proud member of the Autism Rights Movement. ARM represents that Autism is a part of the human being that cannot be taken away from us. After all, Autism affects everything from my 5 senses to my interests and social life.

This book acts as if all Autism is extremely severe and overly negative. Autism is positive, negative, and neutral. For example, I cannot understand human body language very well but I have a deep understanding of animal body language that comes naturally to me as an expression of my Autistic traits. Note that not understanding people's body language is not a negative to me. Why? Because I tell people that I am different and we work together to understand one another! No need to fix what isn't broken.

As for a negative, I suffer from autistic self injury and definitely from other people's bigotry. Autistic Self Injury is a huge problem that communities affected by autism deal with and I do sincerely hope that one day there will be an effective treatment so that I no longer self injure. At the same time I don't at all wish to be cured of my autism because that would mean erasing me as a human being and replacing me with somebody else. Bigotry is my biggest enemy. People have told me that I should not be allowed to breed, that I should not marry, that I do not have a soul, that I an essentially an animal, and don't even get me started on Autism Speaks! Terrible. Excuse. For. An. Organization.

End inhumane treatment of all Autistic People! Viva la Autism Rights!

PS: I have worked with severely affected autistics persons and many high functioning autistics. All those capable of communicating agreed with me on Autism being a part of them. To those who are very negatively affected, let a less ignorant society work towards things that ACTUALLY improve your lives such as speech therapy and Floor-time instead of chelation and electric shock treatments. Do you know there have been children who were killed by their parents because they have Autism? It needs to end! Please, even if you know someone with an ASD, you need to remember that you will never "understand" what it is like.

author: Stephen Atkinson
title: Offence and untruthful rubbish.
content: A disgusting and worthless book. Deeply offensive to anyone with autism or cancer. Imagine children with cancer or autism coming across this piece of unpleasant fiction. As an aside, there is no "autism epidemic"

author: Shayne Robyn
title: Disgusting book
content: I couldn't get past the first few pages of this book, although I was just reading the preview. Disgusting parents, disgusting book, disgusting reviewers (the ones that rated it highly). This book is about a father complaining about how hard his life is because his child isn't "normal", he needs to grow up and realise that all children are different and autism, regardless of "severity", is not something that should make you treat your children like trash. Also, if you are a parent, family member, friend of or work with someone with autism you are not living with autism, only those with ASD are living with autism. Stop equating someone to their disabilities.

author: Tim Culbertson
title: One Star
content: thoughtless

author: HJC
title: I love my neurodiverse family
content: If anyone else feels this way, I'll adopt your autistic child. I love my neurodiverse family!

author: Joseph
title: You are sick and insensitive
content: I have Asperger's, and guess what? It's not that bad. Sure, I'm not Mr. Popular, but I have a few friends because I'm nice to them. I don't do a lot of things friends, why? Because I prefer to keep to myself. Autistic people LIKE being alone. So your kids probably don't feel that bad. A lot of my friends overlook my social awkwardness, because of my kindness. And yeah, I also have some organization problems, but I have good memory to make up for it. A lot of my parents' colleagues have had children die of cancer, and it is horrific. Your children aren't in any danger of death. Can't you be grateful for that? I think you're sending a horrible message to your kids, and you should be ashamed of yourself. I hope YOU get cancer. Then maybe we'll see if you still feel the same way.

author: Butterfly
title: Having experienced both...
content:
I have a son with autism.
I had a daughter with cancer.
She died, slowly, horribly and suffered immense pain and distress.
Her ashes are now in an urn in my living room.
My son is happy and goes to school and is alive.

So I think I am qualified to comment on what is worse, autism or cancer.

author: Michael Speziale
title: Avoid if you read above a third grade level - wish I could give one star
content: Absolute trash, written by a self-absorbed father who can barely convey his disgusting view due to his inability to write.

author: Alie S.
title: Disgusted
content: Why would any parent wish any kind of harm on their child, even if it's just a different type of harm than what they are suffering from currently?

author: Rachel Anschuetz
title: This book is a mistake!
content: As an autistic woman, i thought for sure this book was satire. I was horrified to find not only was it not satire, but there were many people in agreement with this thought process. Is having an autistic kid hard? I'm sure. I never thought for a second my parents didn't love me, or even worse, wished me dead. My soul weeps for children experiencing this reality. I wouldn't recommend this book, or this way of thought, to anyone seeking to experience unconditional love.

author: Jaime A. Heidel
title: The Most Shameful Title for a Book
content: What a sick way to market a book. I haven't read it. I don't care to. With a title like that, there's no reason to see the inside. If the struggle is too much and you would rather see your precious children waste away from cancer, then you should give them up for adoption to a loving home for special needs children. They exist. The title of this book is nothing more than the public shaming of tow children who have more innocence and beauty in their little fingers than you obviously have in your entire being. I don't know whether to be sick, burst into tears or throw something. God help these poor children.

author: Jane
title: Apalling excuse for memoir
content: Self serving, melodramatic and just bad for his kids, not that he cares.

author: DNA
title: Terrible
content: I can't believe you would compare a disability like autism to a life-threatening illness like cancer. Not only is this offensive to people who actually have autism, like me, but also to cancer patients themselves. You're comparing their serious condition to something that isn't actually life-threatening.

author: Amazon Customer
title: ... teen that has both autism and cancer be very glad you only have autism to deal with
content: As a mom with a teen that has both autism and cancer be very glad you only have autism to deal with. How dare you complain about autism. You really wish your child had cancer instead?! Go visit a cancer ward at your local children's hospital. Those kids go thru so much more than anything you ever have to deal with. My son has relapsed and is on the last chance chemo. Because his AUTISM prevents him to be able to handle more intense treatment. There is a good chance that chemo is starting to fail right now and we have to wait a few more weeks before his scan to see if we have to plan for his funeral. HOW DARE YOU COMPLAIN!!!!!

author: Bev
title: Abusive and Self-Serving
content: This is absolutely appalling. Does Mr. Alan seriously believe that his children will never hear of this book? Oh, yes, of course he will explain, "Oh I just meant for the insurance!" or "People often recover from cancer," or some such. Not good enough, not nearly. The damage done to autistic peoply by this sort of thing is immeasureable. And what about the offense to those families who are dealing with cancer? This never should have been published, and Amazon.com has made a poor decision in offering it. Negative 5 stars.

author: Mad Maudlin
title: Eugenics is en vogue.
content: What is wrong with someone who would rather have a child die than be different?  Nazi Germany had opinions on what should be done with the "disabled" - and so the T4 experiments were born.  You can rest assured that autistic people, as well as others, perished in the Nazi conquest to perfect an efficient method of killing before enacting the "Final Solution".  Enjoy.

author: Jess DeVose
title: One Star
content: I hope you get a$$ cancer

author: Jerry McDonald
title: Disgusting!
content: Disgusting. How can a father wish that for his kids? If I could post minus stars, I would.

author: danny
title: clueless
content: What a thoughtless author. He has no idea. Is he really saying he'd rather be in my shoes? My 6 year old boy has lost the ability to move, speak, swallow, even smile. Now he's laying in a hospital bed and he's slowly slipping away. I would never wish this on anyone. He'll still be able to cuddle his kids on their next birthday.

author: Julie Hall
title: um
content: I haven't read the book.  But that is seriously one horrible title.  I have a kid with autism.  It's not always easy, but autism will not KILL him.  This is so offensive to me and i am sure to families out there whose children DO have cancer.  Why do you need to resort to shock value to sell this book?  does it suck?

author: Lex M.
title: Clearly delusional
content: Is this man delusional? He wishes his kids had cancer? Why would I want to read his book? And from the comments, it seems like no one wants to read his book. Put me in a room with this guy so that we can talk. All he has to do is go to Truth365 and he can read stories of parents who wish they never heard the word cancer. Parents whose children are battling cancer today, parents whose children died from the very disease he wishes his children had. Wow-be careful what you wish for Mr. Alan...

author: JRaeDupree
title: Are you insane?
content: Yes, I'm judging this book by its cover. I have absolutely no interest in hearing anything further from either an author or publisher who would inflict a book with this title on the autism community. And there IS a thriving autism community. Shame on you.

author: Dru
title: Cancer is a horrible disease and people who have it suffer so much
content: I'm so sadden by the title of this book.  Cancer is a horrible disease and people who have it suffer so much.  I have a child with autism and I can tell you I do not wish cancer on him, in fact I would not change one thing about him, not even his autism.  He's my gift from God and I will love him and protect him and do whatever I need to do to get him the help he needs.

author: Mrs M.
title: Shame on you!
content:
Shame on you Amazon for selling this!
Shame on you AmericaPublish for publishing this!
Shame on you M. Alan for wishing the worse parents' nightmare upon your adorable children.
If such title was really not your wish and only a marketing trick to grab attention, you really have a serious problem. And if you truly wish this upon your children, you don't deserve them. Every condition is a struggle, be it cancer or autism and we must continue to fight for the better of our children.
Reading the title - you gave up already!!!

author: C. E. Creager
title: Call CPS on this one
content:
I would give no stars if possible.

I am autistic, with a mother currently undergoing treatment for endometrial cancer. This book is tone deaf at best, utterly hateful at worst. This author has some nerve, exploitatively manipulating the pain that the families of cancer patients go through to cast aspersions on a minority population who deserve none of it. Autistics deserve dignity, autonomy, and respect - not this shaming, ableist, repulsive drivel.

I hope these children are taken away from this "father" and put in a home that appreciates and loves them. Given the trend in the U.S. of parents murdering their autistic children, I fear for their safety until that happens.

author: Kimbo
title: Atrocious
content: I had cancer when I was a child. I had friends that I made in the hospital that didn't make it. This is the most appalling thing I've seen in a long time. Wishing potential death on a child is not okay.  This might as well be titled, "I Wish My Kids Would Suffer and Die." Shame on you and anyone else that feels this way.

author: thomas benning
title: Five Stars
content: its banter

author: Potato WIFE
title: How in the HECK do you treat your kids at home if you hate that they are autistic so much you would wish ...
content: Wow!!! How in the HECK do you treat your kids at home if you hate that they are autistic so much you would wish cancer on them!!! They are special children whom you should love no matter what! You're probably the type of person that would have made your woman get an abortion if you had known that sweet child had a disability. You make me sick.
